awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Wide Bandgap Semiconductor Betavoltaic Powered Sensor Controller
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a breakthrough power source for small electronic devices that will move the reality of smart cities and smart rural areas closer to the vision. The center piece of the innovation is the wide bandgap semiconductor betavoltaic power source, essentially an innovative nuclear-based micro-battery. The energy storage density of this power source is estimated to be three orders of magnitude greater than conventional NiMH battery technology. This power innovation will be combined with the very latest in ultra low power electronics and energy harvesting circuitry to realize sensors that are effectively self-powered for the useful life of device. The betavoltaic power source will enable the realization of the 'Internet-of-Things' vision by solving the power challenge, supporting the public good through enhanced safety and security, improved mobility and support for new and disruptive business ventures.

The proposed project will attempt to solve a portion of the power challenge that today limits the implementation and scale of Internet of Things (IoT) solutions. Experts predict billions and possibly trillions of "things" connected by IoT technologies. This requires transformative advances in the science, technology, and engineering. The proposed betavoltaic power source will achieve advancements in all three areas, focused on the power challenge. Although research papers have been published on micro nuclear batteries, the power levels of the previous implementations are insufficient for broad market application. Through the use of novel fabrication techniques and optimal material selection and placement, the proposed power source will achieve at least an order of magnitude improvement in power efficiency over any previous result achieved, with target power efficiency level in excess of 30%. This surpasses the breakout power level required for mass adoption of the new power source. Work on this power source will result in new technology development for enhancing the efficiency of nuclear micro-battery. New semiconductor material processing and fabrication techniques related to the incorporation of radioactive materials will be developed as well as greater understanding of wide band gap semiconductor material behavior under irradiation as applied to radiation-hardened electronics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The reliance of society on electronic devices has never been greater leading to an ever increasing need for electrical power to keep those devices working. In particular, small wireless sensors and smart devices that rely on battery power are today limited in their application and deployment by the limited life of available batteries. AwareAbility Technologies (AAT) has endeavored to develop a battery technology that marries the innovation of solar cells with the long lived power potential of radioisotopes.

Today?s best solar cells are made of semiconductor material that can convert the electromagnetic radiation from the sun into electricity.  AAT?s Phase I and Phase II project have worked to develop a version of that semiconductor solar cell design that is rugged enough to use a small amount of radioactive material as its source of power, rather than the sun.  This radioactive material (radioisotope) can be sourced from nuclear power plants which produce this as a by-product of their operation, and therefore is readily available. 

AAT has worked to develop novel semiconductor devices and methods to incorporate the radioisotope into those devices as part of its Phase II effort, in order to produce a useful amount of power. The power would be used in a very low powered wireless sensor that could be used in remote locations that do not allow for traditional battery replacement or recharging. 

Early Phase II efforts centered on extension and improvements to the silicon carbide (SiC) based power source developed in Phase I. A working prototype was built and tested. However, difficulties were encountered as the team attempted to scale up to a design that could demonstrate power in the milliwatt range. A technical pivot was required to overcome these problems. The team switched from SiC to new high efficiency material for the semi-conductor used as the energy transducer for the power source. 

The results of this pivot were a new ?Gen 3? power source design that employed a far more effective use of the radioisotope with the promise of much higher efficiency result. Novel semi-conductor based solar cells are known for their high efficiency, well in excess of 25%. By employing proper packaging to avoid exposure to the environment, the power source can be scaled to produce power in the milliwatt range using readily available radioisotope sources. Such a power source would have a battery life in excess of 12 years. Although the project was not able fabricate a demonstration quality ?Gen 3? power source, AAT is optimistic that it can complete the fabrication of a working prototype based on this design. The company is pursuing funding for this effort.
